Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient support as it is based on a single study that investigated the effect of the iPhone 12 on only one type of cardiac rhythm management device (ICD).
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the iPhone 12 can disable a cardiac rhythm management device based on the findings of the study. However, it fails to consider alternative explanations or factors that may contribute to the observed effects.
Exist alternative explanation: The study itself acknowledges that other smart devices with magnetic fields could potentially interact with cardiac devices in the same way. Therefore, it is possible that the observed effects are not unique to the iPhone 12 and may apply to other devices as well.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Apple argues the iPhone 12 is not unique in its potential for magnetic interference with medical devices. Apple states that the iPhone 12 does not pose a greater risk of magnetic interference than prior iPhone models.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the impact of the iPhone 12 on cardiac rhythm management devices by stating that it can "disable" them. The study only reports immediate suspension of ICD therapies when the iPhone 12 is brought close to the device.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in the provided claim.
Falters at times: There is no evidence of the claim faltering at times in the provided information.
